title: These Shoulder-Length Haircuts Are Anything But Boring, Say Top Hairstylists
text:
These Shoulder-Length Haircuts Are Anything But Boring, Say Top Hairstylists

From the bob to the bixie, short haircuts have become the style of choice in salons up and down the country. Though they all look incredible, theyâ€™re also pretty high maintenance.Â 

For those who donâ€™t like the idea of booking in for a monthly trim, a midi, shoulder-length cut might be your best bet. Far from mediocre, the in-between length isnâ€™t only much easier to keep sharp â€” itâ€™s also being touted as one of the biggest hair trends for 2026. â€œMid-length cuts donâ€™t have to feel like a long, grown-out bob,â€ says Jordan Jones, stylist and color technician at Taylor Taylor London. â€œThis year, weâ€™re being shown that they can be their own style with layers and careful shaping to create volume and movement, or shine and sophistication. If your bob has grown out and your hair has reached that awkward-length stage, or if youâ€™ve got long locks and fancy a change without going super short, a trendy mid-length style is the cut for you.â€

On Instagram, Londonâ€™s most sought-after stylists The Hair Bros are also championing shoulder-length haircuts with curtain bangs, concave layers, and natural waves. It seems weâ€™ve all got the same idea: Google search for shoulder-length haircuts has risen by 180% recently.

So which shoulder-length haircut will suit you best? Ahead, stylists reveal the biggest shoulder-length haircut trends that everyone can wear.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Shoulder-Length Drape

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Nicolas Flores (@nicolasfloreshair)

Curtain bangs are going nowhere fast, but according to editorial hairstylist and presenter Neil Moodie, you might want to cancel your fringe trim, because itâ€™s increasingly cool to let it grow out a little. â€œGrown-out curtain fringes are great and can make shoulder-length hair look more interesting,â€ he says. The more grown out the fringe, the easier it is to blend into the rest of your hair, particularly if youâ€™re interested in getting a handful of layers to enhance volume and texture, like this style by hairstylist
Nicolas Flores.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Jagged Lob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Callan de Villiers (@callandevilliers)

â€œAs the bob and long bobs have been around for a while, I feel like fringes are making a comeback,â€ says Moodie. â€œThe type of fringe I mean almost looks a bit homemade and very individual. Itâ€™s slightly jagged on the ends and a little uneven.â€ Take a cue from this choppy cut on Callan de Villiers by Cort Bray.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Mane

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Francesca Inverarity (@frankie_inv)

Youâ€™ve heard of the wolf cut (a variation on the shag, occupying a space between wild and relaxed) but â€˜the maneâ€™ is a lot more voluminous. â€œThis is super edgy with lots of texture and a heavy fringe that needs to be worn long and in the eyes so it has plenty of movement,â€ explains Jordan Jones, stylist and color technician at Taylor Taylor London. â€œThe face-framing layers of this cut make it perfect for adding texture and volume to the hair while defining the face.â€

So what should you ask for? â€œA choppy cut with plenty of layers that frame the face and create soft movement,â€ says Jones. â€œThink Billie Eilish and Miley Cyrusâ€™s shaggy â€˜dos.â€ Jones says the look works well with any hair texture. â€œSea salt products are a must-have to give an effortless, freshly tousled finishing touch.â€ Take inspiration from this look by Francesca Inverarity.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Shoulder-Length Afro

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Diliana van Rijn (@diliana.nvr)

â€œAs we move into spring and summer, I think weâ€™ll be seeing a lot more natural afro and curly hair in medium lengths,â€ says celebrity hairdresser Lorraine Dublin, much like this beautiful, fluffed-out afro on Diliana van Rijn. â€œIn the colder months, hair thrives better in protective styles, so as the weather heats up, weâ€™ll be seeing afro hair in its natural state â€” with bold colors, too.â€

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Half Up, Half Down

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by dylan bradshaw DUBLIN (@dylanbradshawdublin)

â€œAnother trend that will continue to be popular is the half-up, half-down style,â€ says Lorraine, â€œespecially with hair extensions.â€ She continues: â€œYou can add an ombre hair color to the ends and combine this with a natural, soft, body wave.â€ Gemma Murphy from Dylan Bradshaw, Dublin,Â totally nails the cute in-between style here.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Collarbone Cut

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Jessenia Robayo (@jesseniaspallet)

â€œThe collarbone cut is so popular right now,â€ says Tyler Moore, stylist at Live True London. He prefers a blunt edge and no layering, but the look works equally well with a little bit of texture. â€œThis style can be paired with a fringe for an ultra chic look, and it works great on both straight and wavy or textured hair.â€ We love this look on Jessenia Robayo.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Flip

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Alexia Colombo (@iamalexiaclb)

The Hair Bros say a shoulder-length cut is its own style and that itâ€™s important not to leave all of the hair one length. â€œThis will end up looking heavy, as if it were a shorter bob. A middy haircut should be full of texture and life and feel fun and playful. Itâ€™s great for anyone who wants to cut their long hair short but isnâ€™t quite ready to brave a bob.â€ Flip your hair to one side for more of a natural, lived-in feel, like this cut on Alexia Colombo. â€œAs always, just a few products and some air should be enough to style this cut,â€ added The Hair Bros.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The â€™90s Lob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by The Labartory (@the.labartory)

The â€™90s lob (aka long bob) is going to be everywhere again this year, says Tyler. â€œThis is a layered, mid-length long bob Ã  la Rachel from Friends. Think of it as a more retro twist on the wolf cut with slightly longer layers and a sleeker texture.â€ Dreamed up by @the.labartory on Instagram, this lob is both glossy and textured.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Hi-Shine Lob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Emiliano Breit (@emilianobreitsalon)

â€œEmbrace modern glamour with a super blunt cut with clean, sharp lines,â€ says Jones, like this cut created by Emiliano Breit. â€œThis style looks best when cut around the collarbone and is perfectly set off with mirror-shine hair.â€ This is all about the condition of your hair, so make sure to use hydrating and nourishing conditioners or oils to create a super sleek style. KÃ©rastase Elixir Ultime Lâ€™Original Hair Oil, is a favorite among stylists.

â€œIf you are a brunette or darker, ask for a gloss color to add depth and shine,â€ adds Jones. â€œEven opting for a Brazilian blow-dry or straightening treatment will help to put the finishing touches on this look.â€

DashDividers_1_500x100

Lived-In Lengths

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by ğ‘…ğ“Šğ’·ğ“ ğ’¯ğ“Šğ‘’ğ“ˆğ’¹ğ’¶ğ“ ğ¸ğ“‹ğ‘’ğ“‡ğ“ˆ (@didntcatchthat)

â€œWhy is shoulder-length hair commonly perceived to be bad?â€ wrote The Hair Bros on Instagram. â€œItâ€™s not!â€ This modern shoulder-length cut by hairstylist Liam Russell on Ruby Tuesday Evers has inspired the Brosâ€™ work in-salon over the past few months. The bedhead texture and mussed-up fringe give the medium length great shape.

DashDividers_1_500x100

The Top-Heavy Cut

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by ğ•°ğ–’ğ–ğ–‘ğ– ğ•¶ğ–ğ–“ğ–Œğ–˜ğ–™ğ–”ğ–“ (@lemzkingston)

The shag, the mullet, the shulletâ€¦ Whatever you call the â€˜00s most popular cut, it always seems to be evolving, as illustrated by Emily Kingston, stylist and colorist at Blue Tit Clapton. Proving the cut looks just as incredible on curly hair, the trick is to emphasize lots of volume around the top of the head and taper the lengths right down to the bottom so that hair sits just below the collarbone.

DashDividers_1_500x100

Flipped Side Bangs

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by â‹† Billie Brown â‹† (@billiebrown)

The flipped side bang perfectly accentuates a shoulder-length cut, says Jones, like this style on Billie Brown. â€œCurtain bangs have moved on, and side bangs from the early â€™00s are back. For fringe lovers who want a bit more excitement this year, this style flatters most face shapes and essentially frames the face with disconnected, slightly longer bangs. Itâ€™s not dramatic and easy to tuck behind your ear, pin to one side, or sweep across the forehead with a big, bouncy blow-dry.â€

Jones says it looks great on wavy, thicker hair in particular, styled as if itâ€™s been casually flipped over. â€œTo keep it on trend, itâ€™s best worn loose and tousled. Add spritzes of dry shampoo on the roots for second-day hair to amplify the volume and add a bit of texture.â€

If you have finer hair, ask for a modern micro-shag or wolf-shag with strategic layering that adds volume and texture without making the hair look sparse,â€ advises Stenson. This cut on Linasha never fails to inspire.Â 

The Shaggy Lob

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Catherine Gibbs (@ccatherinee.g)

â€œThe textured lob [aka long bob] will continue its quiet takeover,â€ says Rodger. â€œItâ€™s mid-length, slightly undone, and effortlessly cool â€” the kind of cut that behaves beautifully through winter,â€ he adds. Itâ€™s also a seasonal all-rounder, and easy to air-dry in the warmer months, too. â€œI love how it slips under scarves and coats without losing shape, and it gives hair that natural, lived-in movement,â€ continues Rodger, who says itâ€™s perfect for wavy and lightly curly hair. â€œAsk your stylist for a neck-to-shoulder graze with feathered, textured ends, and a soft, natural finish,â€ suggests Rodger. Hairstylist Catherine Gibbs nails the look here.

The One-Length Bob

The 2026 update is lighter than its previous counterpart, says Walters, and it sits in what he refers to as the magic zone: â€œJust above the collarbone and never shorter than the jawline,â€ adds Walters, like this cut by Miho Mai. â€œThis sweet spot creates a clean, graphic silhouette without sacrificing softness.â€ What gives it a modern edge is the invisible layering: â€œThese are subtle, sliced-in shorter pieces hidden underneath,â€ says Walters. â€œThese secret layers act like built-in movement, allowing the bob to swing, breathe, and catch the light in all the right ways.â€

The Chin-Length Bob

Gianettos says that thereâ€™s something so chic about a sharp bob that grazes the chin and that it can elevate any outfit. â€œIt feels very confident, effortless, cool-girl,â€ says Giannetos. â€œIt can be worn wavy for an everyday style or straight for a very sleek, edgy look,â€ â€” much like this cut on Meredith Duxbury. â€œI like to use Lâ€™Oreal Parisâ€™ Sleek It Iron Straight Hairspray to tame any frizz that distracts from the moment,â€ says Giannetos.

The Bixie Cut

The bixie â€” bob meets pixie â€” is heading into 2026 with us, and for good reason: itâ€™s soft, wearable, and short enough to feel fresh, says Rodger. â€œThis is a sweet spot between a bob and a pixie, and itâ€™s ideal for anyone tempted to go shorter without committing to a full pixie,â€ says Rodger. For the best result, Rodger suggests asking for a chin-to-collarbone bob with crisp, blunt ends and minimal layering. â€œKeep it sleek or lightly textured depending on your hair type,â€ he says.

They took the gravity (or levity) of their material and elevated what was on the page to make it even better. In a year that tested us all â€” seriously, we barely survived â€” through their work these artists gave us so much, a reprieve from the hellscape of our social feeds and portrayals of the human experience that revealed a little more about ourselves. Every awards season, I remind you that while weâ€™ve long since divested from the gatekeeping archaic institutions that consistently exclude Black folks from legacy awards, giving recognition where itâ€™s due still matters.Â 

When Sinners was undoubtedly (when it came to box office performance and cultural impact) the movie of the year, and yet still is left off of multiple (white) criticsâ€™ year-end lists and awards predictions, itâ€™s more and more evident that we need to uplift our own (letâ€™s not forget that winning an NAACP Image Award should be just as big of an honor as getting an Oscar). We must acknowledge the best Black performances beyond the one or two actors that legacy awards deem worthy of being their annual token, albeit deserved, inclusions. We refuse to settle for crumbs. We get to exist in a timeline where a multitude of Black artistic expressions are celebrated. â€˜Tis the season to look back on the best of the best of the year and the best, as always, is Black as hell â€” whether they get accolades from certain governing bodies or not.

These are the performances Iâ€™ve been yelling at you about all year. So, here is my exhaustive, definitive, and still not long enough list of 2025â€™s best Black film performances.Â 

Michael B. Jordan, SinnersÂ 

Five years ago, I wrote a piece called â€œShouldnâ€™t Michael B. Jordan Have An Oscar Nomination By Now?.â€ In it, I argued that Jordan was long overdue for a nomination for an Academy Award. In 2020, the MBJ role in contention was his performance as real-life social justice lawyer Bryan Stevenson in Just Mercy. Despite being one of the most famous, talented, bankable heartthrobs in Hollywood, he hasnâ€™t garnered the same accolades his contemporaries of past generations had at his age (see DiCaprio, Damon, Cruise, Pitt). It may be five years late, but Jordan is finally in contention for a Best Actor nod for his portrayal of Smoke and Stack, the prodigal twins of Sinners. I bring up Jordanâ€™s awards chances not because I think a nomination or win would impact the quality of his work, but because after these performances, he deserves every accolade available to him in this industry. As Smoke and Stack, Jordan shows off range many of his detractors will swear he doesnâ€™t have. In each scene, with a tilt of his head or the looseness of his swagger, Jordan carves out each twinâ€™s mannerisms uniquely enough that you are rooting for Smoke while holding your breath waiting for Stack to mess things up, and subtly enough that itâ€™s clear the brothers are inseparable and to an untrained eye, sometimes indecipherable.Â 

It takes a lot of skill to carry an ambitious masterpiece like Sinners. And to put it simply, the film does not work without the precision and thoughtfulness of Jordanâ€™s performances. Weâ€™ve been watching him grow as an actor since he was coming of age in All My Children, The Wire, and Friday Night Lights, to young powerhouse showings in Fruitvale Station and Creed. Then, there were the bonafide blockbusters in Creed II and Black Panther. Jordan has proven â€” repeatedly â€“Â  that heâ€™s earned his status as a Movie Star. Sinners is proof heâ€™s done something so many of his peers only dream of: reached his potential and surpassed it.

Cynthia Erivo, Wicked: For GoodÂ 

Yes, I am one of the few critics who actually liked Wicked: For Good. I stand by my review of the film, which argued that while the movie is the weaker half in the two-part adaptation of the Broadway musical, it did right by its source material and delivered a thrilling, emotional, and endearing conclusion. And about Erivo, who is undoubtedly the best Elphaba of all time, I wrote, â€œmany headlines about Wicked: For Good have focused on Ariana Grande, and while itâ€™s true she is great in this sequel and that itâ€™s more Glindaâ€™s movie than Elphabaâ€™s, Erivo is still firing on all cylinders, delivering a timeless performance that is also worthy of unadulterated praise. Throughout Wicked: For Good, Elphaba goes from fugitive freedom fighter, to heartbroken friend and exasperated sister, to frustrated revolutionary, to lover in mourning, to resigned martyr. Itâ€™s a depressing arc that sees the optimism of progressivism dashed with a big dose of witch-melting water. The simplicity of the message â€” that doing good comes at a cost, that no matter your intentions, things donâ€™t always work in your favor, and that facism may take on a new face but itâ€™s an ever-present threat â€” is the point.â€Â 

The Wicked instalments are going to go down in history as two of the biggest movies of this decade, if not the century, and that will largely be because Cynthia Erivo gave us an unforgettable and undeniable Elphaba.

Tessa Thompson, HeddaÂ 

Not to keep quoting myself but this is what I wrote about Hedda in my review back in October: â€œSet in 1950s England, as the party devolves into shambles â€” mostly orchestrated by Hedda herself â€” Hedda goes from a simmering conversation about what happens to a woman bound by her circumstances to a sexy psychological thriller about class, power, and ambition. As the events of the evening unfold, Hedda becomes more and more quietly unhinged and Tessa Thompson is so magnetic, oozing with charisma, that you canâ€™t look away and you canâ€™t help but root for one of the messiest women in cinematic history. I like to think of this column as my own Oscars. The Academy is going to deem their own â€œbest of the bestâ€ come March 2026, and while Tessa Thompsonâ€™s name should definitely be on that ballot, in this space, I get to say whatâ€™s the best of the year and I am telling you â€” unequivocally â€” that Hedda is one of the best films and performances of the past year. Period.â€Â

Wunmi Mosaku, SinnersÂ 

As mentioned above, SinnersÂ is Michael B. Jordanâ€™s showcase. But itâ€™s more than just a vehicle for MBJâ€™s movie stardom or a Southern gothic horror flick like itâ€™s been billed. It is that, but itâ€™s also an enthusiastic musical, a consequential period drama, and an earnest romance. Itâ€™s the latter that piqued my interest the most, and its execution is swoon-inducing. I already knew Wunmi Mosaku was a star, but in this role, sheâ€™s assertive, luminous and so damn sexy. Annie is the heart ofÂ Sinners. Sheâ€™s also its hero.Â Â â€œI like to think of Annie as Smokeâ€™s other other half, like Stack is,â€ Mosaku said when we interviewed her in April. â€œStack is one side of him, but Annie is another side of him. Sheâ€™s his protector, lover, mother, safe place. She is his sanctuary.â€ Annieâ€™s knowledge of the spiritual world also saves everyoneâ€™s â€” including Smokeâ€™s â€” asses. â€œShe moves with purpose. She moves with strength and power. She has such an anchored spirit and is so in tune with the other stuff that we canâ€™t see or feel or hear. She sees and feels and hears it.â€

Ayo Edebiri, After The Hunt

Iâ€™m ready to be right about After The Hunt. It might take a few years, but I swear this film will outlive its discourse. The Luca Guadagnino-directed drama documents a moment in time â€” a disturbing, delicate, and awkward moment in time, one that we are still navigating. And for better or worse, shouldnâ€™t we have art that reflects these times? Thatâ€™s what I wrote at the time of the filmâ€™s release and I stand by it: â€œWith time, After The Hunt may hold up as a page to be read in the chapter of this so-called cultural reckoning. Think of it as a sleek and uncomfortable time capsule of the past half decade of #MeToo discourse, or as a character study of flawed intellectuals desperately attempting to perform their values while clinging to the facade of their respective identities. Or, as Ayo Edebiri told me, After The Hunt is a â€œRorschach testâ€ that interrogates your discomfort.

And itâ€™s in that discomfort where Edebiri and the rest of the cast (Andrew Garfield and Julia Roberts are both excellent as usual) shine. If youâ€™ve seen The Bear or Bottoms, you know Edebiri is a star who can play awkward better than anyone. It was this role that reminded me that sheâ€™s going to be around for a very long time. Going toe-to-toe with icon Roberts without flinching and sparring effortlessly with Oscar nominee Garfield, Edebiri in After The Hunt is one of those star-making performances that weâ€™ll look back on in awe.

David Jonsson, The Long Walk

David Jonsson doesnâ€™t get enough credit for being one of the most exciting and talented working actors of his generation. I officially fell in love with him in Rye Lane, one of the best rom-coms of the past decade, and this year, he showed versatility and depth in his choices. In The Long Walk, Jonsson anchors the filmâ€™s brutal premise: a near-future America where teenage boys volunteer for a televised endurance contest that demands they keep walking above the minimum speed or face lethal consequences. Jonssonâ€™s performance is achingly vulnerable. As the miles stack up and the rules tighten (three warnings, then youâ€™re shot), Jonsson charts the slow erosion of bravado into something far more fragile.

As realization sets in that survival isnâ€™t just about strong legs, itâ€™s about memory, friendship, and the will to keep choosing the next step, Jonsson is especially magnetic in the quieter stretches, trading jokes with fellow walkers (and delivering electric chemistry with Cooper Hoffman) at dawn, bargaining with himself as the road narrows, and letting grief and resolve flicker across his face when the crowdâ€™s cheers turn hollow. Rather than leaning into the spectacle of the contest, Jonsson makes the walk feel personal. With each warning comes a small heartbreak and each mile an excruciating decision. grounding the dystopia in intimacy and reminding us that the most powerful performances donâ€™t outrun the story; they walk straight through it.

Naomi Ackie, Mickey 17

Itâ€™s still baffling to me that Bong Joon Hoâ€™s Mickey 17 flopped because itâ€™s so weird and wonderful, and the kind of original movie from one of the greatest living directors that we need more of. But I refuse to let people forget about Naomi Ackieâ€™s performance as Nasha, the love interest to Pattinsonâ€™s aloof Mickey. Nasha is wild, extremely weird, and an enforcer in a futuristic universe where civilian space travel to another planet sets it apart from our current reality, but a psychotic tyrannical politician with a god complex (Mark Ruffaloâ€™s Kenneth Marshall) makes it feel eerily familiar.

Hereâ€™s what I wrote back in March: â€œWhileÂ Mickey 17Â is, by all accounts, a showcase of Pattinsonâ€™s unquantifiable talent, itâ€™s also a stunning display of how reliably formidableÂ Naomi AckieÂ is. Sheâ€™s one of the brightest talents working right now, and the weirder she gets, the more wonderful it is to watch. Mickey is clueless, compliant, and a bit dense. Nasha is clever, confident, and fearless. Nasha could easily be relegated to a girlfriend-of-the-hero stereotype, a disposable plot device, but in Bongâ€™s script, sheâ€™s assertive, motivated, and layered. And in Ackieâ€™s hands, Nasha leaps off the page and dazzles on screen.â€

Damson Idris, F1

After captivating audiences asÂ Franklin Saint inÂ Snowfall, Damson Idris had cemented himself as a young actor to watch in Hollywood. He shifted gears â€” literally â€” into high-octane territory with his leading role inÂ F1, the Formula 1 racing filmÂ from director Joseph Kosinski and co-starring Brad Pitt. I didnâ€™t love F1, but it was one of the biggest movies of the year and the things that do work about the film are thanks in large part to Idris, who brings charisma and surprising vulnerability to his portrayal of hotshot driver Joshua Pierce.

Whether heâ€™s embodying a South Central kingpin or donning a racing suit opposite Hollywood heavyweights, Idris brings depth, precision, and a quiet confidence that continues to set him apart. And as Unbotheredâ€™s very ownÂ Christa EduafoÂ found out when she sat down with him earlier this year in New York City, the actor is well aware that his Black female fanbase bet big on Damson Idris stock early. And with F1, itâ€™s clear our investment has paid off.

Chase Infiniti, Teyana Taylor & Regina Hall, One Battle After AnotherÂ 

The Black women characters in One Battle After Another have elicited divisive responses. Some critics have written off Teyana Taylorâ€™s Perfidia Beverly Hills as a sexualized stereotype with limited screen time and an underdeveloped character arc. In her Black Girl Watching Substack, Brooke Obie writes, â€œBlack women are little more than props and plot devicesâ€ and that â€œ[director Paul Thomas] Anderson isnâ€™t commenting on the white male fetishization of Black women, heâ€™s directly participating in it.â€ While Angelica Jade Bastien for Vulture says, â€œThe Black women of the film are lightning rods for the most forceful conversations the film can bear, and itâ€™s thrilling to watch them embody what Andersonâ€™s script can only loosely hold.â€

Thereâ€™s a lot to say about how Paul Thomas Anderson depicts Perfidia, Chase Infinitiâ€™s Willa, and Regina Hallâ€™s Deandra (I agree mostly with both Obie and Bastien and their reviews are required supplementary reading material post-watch of OBAA), but of all the critiques of the execution of the lofty ideas of revolution that PTA puts forth in the film, nothing negative can be said about the performances given by these three enigmatic actors. Infiniti is the breakout of the film, playing an almost grown up Willa (the daughter of DiCaprioâ€™s Pat and Taylorâ€™s Perfidia) with quiet resolve and appropriate teen angst. Itâ€™s one of the most stunning breakout performances Iâ€™ve ever seen and Infiniti should have her pick of roles in the aftermath of this movieâ€™s success.

As for Hall and Taylor, we knew how talented they were â€” though in different mediums: Taylor as an artist, dancer, and creative director and Hall as a comedic genius. In this film, even if I wish the material lived up to their efforts, both are able to showcase their abilities to give grounding, affecting, dramatic performances. Deandra and Perfidia are in conversation with each other, showing two sides of how to be a revolutionary, and Hall and Taylorâ€™s performances are striking. While Perfidia is loud, brash, emotional, reckless, and boisterous, Deandra is methodical, focused, and intentional. One Battle After Another has been hailed as PTAâ€™s greatest masterpiece and donâ€™t get me wrong, I do think the movie is a triumph, but letâ€™s be clear on why itâ€™s great: Chase Infiniti, Teyana Taylor and Regina Hall.

Edi Gathegi, Superman

Superman was one of my favorite movies of the year. And while the main cast trio of David Corenswet, Rachel Brosnahan, and Nicholas Hoult, Edi Gathegiâ€™s Mister Terrific was a surprising delight. Mister Terrific emerges as one of Supermanâ€™s smartest anchors, threading intellect through a story preoccupied with power, trust, and what the world expects its heroes to be. As the film tracks Clark Kent navigating a public increasingly skeptical of Supermanâ€™s unchecked strength â€” while Lex Luthorâ€™s machinations test the limits of truth, tech, and influence â€” Gathegiâ€™s Mister Terrific operates in the grey area where ethics meet engineering. Heâ€™s the one parsing data while everyone else argues optics, designing solutions as Superman wrestles with the cost of being a symbol.

Mister Terrific is decisive, grounding the filmâ€™s big ideals in method and consequence. Gathegi plays him as a moral mathematician, weighing outcomes with calm authority, so when the plot pivots from spectacle to strategy, his presence feels essential. Itâ€™s a performance that could have easily gone unnoticed, but Gathegi makes it unforgettable.

Andre Holland, Love, Brooklyn

Andre Holland gives Rachael Abigail Holderâ€™s Love, Brooklyn its bruised, beating heart, turning a deceptively small story about dating in the city into something quietly expansive. As Roger, a writer drifting between relationships, neighborhoods, and versions of himself, Holland captures the ache of romantic limbo with a performance thatâ€™s all soft edges and sharp self-awareness.

The film unfolds across intimate Brooklyn spaces â€” apartments that feel borrowed, late-night conversations that blur into morning, chance encounters that reopen old wounds â€” as Roger navigates his lingering bond with his ex (Nicole Beharie) and a tentative new connection (DeWanda Wise). Holland plays these emotional crosscurrents with exquisite restraint, letting hesitation, guilt, and longing flicker across his face before a single word lands. What makes his work so compelling is how deeply he understands the filmâ€™s thesis: that love isnâ€™t always about grand declarations, but about timing, honesty, and the courage to stop hiding in the in-between. In Hollandâ€™s hands, Roger is funny, charming, frustrating, and achingly recognizable; heâ€™s a man learning, step by step, how to choose presence over comfort. Holland doesnâ€™t get enough credit for consistently delivering devastating and entertaining performances.

Susan Chardy, On Becoming A Guinea FowlÂ 

Susan Chardy gives On Becoming a Guinea Fowl its emotional spine, guiding us through Rungano Nyoniâ€™s darkly surreal reckoning with family silence and collective denial. As Shula, Chardy moves through the aftermath of her uncleâ€™s sudden death â€” discovered on a roadside at night â€” and the elaborate funeral rituals that follow, where aunties organize, gossip circulates, and everyone seems determined to smooth over the past rather than confront it.

While the film slips between realism and dreamlike interludes (guinea fowl skittering through memory, musical detours that feel like pressure valves), Chardy remains piercingly grounded, registering the weight of long-buried truths about abuse and complicity without ever spelling them out. Watch how she listens at the kitchen table, how her stillness cuts through the noise of ceremony, how her face hardens almost imperceptibly as the cost of silence becomes clear. Chardy doesnâ€™t just play a woman at a funeral, she embodies the exhaustion of being awake in a room determined to keep sleeping, making Shulaâ€™s quiet resistance the filmâ€™s most radical act.

Daâ€™Vine Joy Randolph, Eternity

After Daâ€™Vine Joy Randolph won the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for The Holdovers, I was so excited to see her move into starring roles that were worthy of her talent. Playing secondary to Miles Teller in a rom-com starring Elizabeth Olsen wasnâ€™t exactly what I had in mind. But Eternity surprised me, and Randolph is exceptional in it. This is what I wrote about the film last month: â€œAnna, the character, could easily fall into the magical negro trope, a one-note sidekick there in service of the white lead, but in Randolphâ€™s hands (and thanks to her hysterical dynamic with Joanâ€™s AC Ryan played by John Early), sheâ€™s more than that. Anna is the filmâ€™s constant comedic relief, and sheâ€™s also its moral center, a grounding force thatâ€™s there to remind Larry of the life he built with Joan for decades, while making us laugh repeatedly. Thatâ€™s the power of Daâ€™Vine Joy Randolph.â€

View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Unbothered (@r29unbothered)

Delroy Lindo & Miles Caton in Sinners

I couldnâ€™t end this list without mentioning Delroy Lindo and Miles Caton in Sinners. These two performances â€” one by a seasoned actor who has a career full of riveting characters, and the other by a brand new talent whose future is so blindingly bright â€” are just as integral to the success of Sinners as Jordanâ€™s portrayal of Smoke and Stack or Mosakuâ€™s Annie.

Lindo plays Delta Slim, a boozy blues musician who reluctantly agrees to play at the twins new juke joint. Catonâ€™s Sammie is an aspiring musician who is eager to join his cousin in their new business venture. Both are at opposite ends of their musical pursuits, just like Caton and Lindo are at very different moments in their careers. But both characters are bound by their love of the blues, and their allegiance to their communities. While Sammie is naive, impatient, and yearning for adulthood, Delta Slim is wise, heedless yeet unflappable, and the surprising steady voice when the juke joint descends into chaos.

In a perfect world, both Lindo and Caton would be swatting away awards for these performances, but whether or not they are showered with the praise and accolades they deserve, both actors gave two of the most exhilarating performances on screen in 2025.

The dreams you begin to believe in now have the power to become real.Â Â 

Taurus Sun & Rising:

Taurus, January begins with the Cancer Full Moon on January 3rd, activating your communication, learning, and creative expression sector. This is a moment of culmination tied to the last six months, especially around how you speak up, share your ideas, write, teach, or tell your story. Then the tone shifts dramatically in the final third of the month. Gemini Sun & Rising:

You may receive clarity around whatâ€™s sustainable and whatâ€™s draining you financially or energetically. The Capricorn New Moon around January 18th is an ideal moment to set intentions around financial cleanup, long-term investments, or releasing attachments that feel too heavy to carry into this new cycle. This is about taking responsibility for your futureâ€¦ not fearfully, but strategically.

The final third of the month brings a noticeable lift. Then, Neptune enters Aries on January 26th, illuminating your community, friendships, and long-term dreams for the next decade. This is where hope returns. Youâ€™re reminded that you donâ€™t have to figure everything out aloneâ€¦ your people, your collaborators, your future allies are finding you. January ultimately shifts you from survival mode into vision mode. And thatâ€™s a powerful way to begin a year of one.

Cancer Sun & Rising:

Cancer, January is your personal reset. Your annual New Moon arrives early, on January 3rd, in your sign, marking one of the most important moments of your entire year. This is a rebirth point, emotionally, energetically, and intuitively. The past six months have likely asked you to release old identities, patterns, or versions of yourself that no longer felt safe or true. Now, you get to choose who youâ€™re becoming. You may feel more sensitive, reflective, or inward at the start of the year, but thatâ€™s because your intuition is loud and clear. This New Moon asks you to trust your instincts and set intentions that honor how you want to feel, not just what you want to achieve.

At the same time, Mars spends most of January in Capricorn, directly opposing your sign and activating your partnership sector. Relationships â€” romantic, professional, and personal â€” are front and center. This can bring clarity around commitment, boundaries, and shared responsibility. You may be asked to meet others halfway, even if that feels uncomfortable at first.
